Dear Mr. Laidacker:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
A six-month provisional certificate of approval is recommended. If you do not contest the
issuance of a provisional license, you must indicate so in writing; this may be included in
your corrective action plan or in a separate document. If you contest the issuance of a
provisional certificate of approval, you must notify this office in writing and an
administrative hearing will be scheduled. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional
license, you must still submit an acceptable corrective action plan.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Stephanie Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE

ALLEGATION:
Former staff member at facility was conducted unwarranted/improper restraints.
One youth was restrained multiple times. Restraints were not always documented.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on February 7, 2022. Complainant
said it was common for “leadership” to direct staff to write up restraints as “escorts”
so that they did not have to “deal with the scrutiny of restraint numbers or
paperwork”. Complainant said she witnessed Staff 1 go into restraints as a first
2

option instead of using any de-escalation. Complainant said the only youth she can
remember Staff 1 doing this with was Youth F however she was unable to remember
the exact dates restraints occurred. Complainant said most staff that have come
from the Evart Youth Center campus in the last few months have a tendency to go
straight to hands on instead of using de-escalation techniques however was not able
to give specific staff, youth, or dates regarding these restraints.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth A
said she has been placed at New Hope since August 2021. Youth A said she has
been in one restraint since living there. Youth A said she was mad at a peer who
was outside and was trying to get outside and staff would not allow her to get
outside to the peer she was mad at. Youth A said she has seen other youth put into
restraints but is not aware of all the circumstances surrounding those restraints.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth B
said she has been placed at New Hope for about one year. Youth B said she has
only been in one restraint since being placed at New Hope and could not remember
the exact reason why. Youth B said she has seen many restraints over the year and
said they are all done because of youth either hurting themselves or others. Youth B
said it was not very often when youth are restrained. Youth B did not have any
concerns about restraints at New Hope.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth C
said she has been placed at New Hope for about three months. Youth C said she
has never been restrained while at New Hope. Youth C said she has witnessed
other youth be restrained. Youth C said youth are restrained if they are “easy to
push around”, when asked to clarify what this meant Youth C said the youth that are
“weak” or will “not stick up for themselves”. Youth C said the only restraints she has
seen have been due to youth trying to assault staff.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth D
said she has been placed at New Hope since November 9, 2021. Youth D said she
has never been placed in a restraint at New Hope. Youth D said she has witnessed
other youth being restrained and it was always due to the youth either hurting
themselves or others. Youth D said she did not have any concerns about the
restraints she witnessed.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth E
said she has been placed at New Hope since November 2021. Youth E said she has
never been restrained or witnessed any other youth placed in a restraint since being
at New Hope.
Youth F was interviewed via telephone on February 9, 2022. Youth F said she
“barely” remembers being placed at New Hope stating it was “a year ago”. Youth F
said she remembers being restrained for no reason but could not remember the staff
3

members who restrained her, the dates/days, or times of any of the restraints, or any
of the details surrounding the restraints.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4, 2022. Staff 2
said she has worked at New Hope since April 2021. Staff 2 said she has not seen
any unjustified restraints within the last six months Staff 2 said she has been
involved in several restraints with Staff 1 and Youth F. Staff 2 said Youth F would
target Staff 1 and Staff 2 as they held her accountable for her actions, and she did
not like that. Staff 2 said all the restraints she completed with Youth F were justified
and usually done due to Youth F’s assaults on staff. Staff 2 said she worked most of
her shifts with Staff 1 and she never saw Staff 1 complete unjustified restraints. Staff
2 said she has never been directed to write restraints up as escorts.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4, 2022. Staff 3
said she has been at New Hope for three years. Staff 3 said in the last six months
she has not seen or heard of the staff doing any unjustified restraints with any of the
youth. Staff 3 said all restraints are uploaded to MiSACWIS. Staff 3 said she has
never been directed to or has she directed staff to write restraints up as escorts.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4, 2022, and via
telephone on February 16, 2022. Staff 4 said has worked at New Hope for just over
two years. Staff 4 said seldom are restraints done on her shifts however when she
has seen them conducted, they are always justified. Staff 4 said she has observed
several restraints with Youth F and they were typically all due to Youth F hurting
other’s, either staff or youth. Staff 4 said she has never been directed to write
restraints up as escorts.
Case Manager Z was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4,
2022 and via telephone on February 16, 2022. Case Manager Z said she has
been working at New Hope since January 3, 2022. Case Manager Z said she has
not seen or heard of any restraints with the youth that are unwarranted. Case
Manager Z denied any youth speaking to her of concerns with any restraints since
working at New Hope. Case Manager Z said she has never been told or heard other
staff being told to write restraints up as escorts.
Chief Administrator 2 was interviewed via telephone on February 10, 2022.
Chief Administrator said she had never witnessed any staff preform any unjustified
restraints in her time at New Hope. Chief Administrator denied any youth telling her
about unjustified or concerns with any restraints.
Documents Reviewed:
 A random sample of MiSACWIS Physical Restraint Incident Reports were
reviewed with Youth F, Staff 1, and within the last six months:
4

o Incident Report 125110182 dated 11/1/2021 involving Staff 1, Staff 2,
and Youth F. Restraint was completed due to Youth F attempting self-
harm and when stopped Youth F assaulted staff several times.
o Incident Report 125270182 dated 11/2/2021 involving Staff 1, Staff 2
and Youth F. Restraint was completed due to Youth F assaulting
another youth.
o Incident Report 125260184 dated 11/03/2021 involving Staff 1, Youth
F, and another direct care staff. Restraint was completed due to Youth
F assaulting another youth.
o Incident Reported 126160183 dated 11/11/2021 involving Staff 3, Staff
4, Youth F and another direct care staff. Restraint was completed due
to Youth F hitting her fists on the TV in order to break it. Due to the
concern for harm if she broke the TV glass she was restrained.
o Incident Report 126160184 dated 11/11/2021 involving Staff 4 and
Youth F. Restraint was completed due to Youth F assaulting staff.
o Incident Report 128960184 dated 12/30/2021 involving Staff 2, Staff 3,
Staff 4, Youth I, and another direct care staff. Restraint was completed
due to Youth I self-harming and assaulting staff.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.159 Resident restraint.
(4) The written policy shall only permit the licensee to
restrain a child for the following circumstances:
(a) To prevent injury to the child, self-injury, or injury to
others.
(b) As a precaution against escape or truancy.
(c) When there is serious destruction of property that
places a child or others at serious threat of violence or
injury if no intervention occurs.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in compliance with resident restraint.
Interviews with youth, staff, and review of restraint
documentation all report restraints being conducted in justified
circumstances.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Case Manager is not qualified for her position.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth A
said she has been placed at New Hope since August 2021 and identified Case
Manager Z as her current case manager and Complainant as her previous case
manager.
5

Youth B was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth B
said she has been placed at New Hope for about one year. Youth B identified Case
Manager Z as her current case manager and Complainant as her previous case
manager.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth C
said she has been placed at New Hope for about three months. Youth C identified
her case manager as Case Manager Z and said prior to that it was Complainant.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth D
said she has been placed at New Hope since November 9, 2021. Youth D identified
her case manager as Case Manager Z and said prior to that it was Complainant.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth E
said she has been placed at New Hope since November 2021. Youth E said she is
unaware of who the case manager is at New Hope.
Youth F was interviewed via telephone on February 9, 2022. Youth F said she
“barely” remembers being placed at New Hope stating it was “a year ago”. Youth F
said she does not know who her case manager was when she was at New Hope.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4, 2022. Staff 2
said Case Manager Z is the current case manager and prior to her Complainant was
doing all of the case management work. Staff 2 said Chief Administrator 2 was listed
as the case manager however Complainant did all the paperwork.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4, 2022. Staff 3
said Case Manager Z is the current case manager however prior to that was
Complainant. Staff 3 said Complainant was working with Chief Administrator 2 and
Chief Administrator 2 was sitting in on all of Complainant’s meetings with youth or
other professionals.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4, 2022. Staff 4
said Complainant was the case manager and now Case Manager Z is in that role.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on February 7, 2022. Complainant
said she was originally hired as a direct care staff. Complainant said she completed
her bachelor level internship under the case manager during the summer of 2021.
Complainant said after her internship she stayed in an administrative role and was
helping out with case management as well as doing direct care work. Complainant
said on September 30, 2021, she was promoted to assistant case manager as the
former case manager had left. Complainant said she was completing all case
management duties and Chief Administrator 2 oversaw her work and approved
everything she was completing. Complainant said Chief Administrator 2 was not
sitting in on any of her meetings but would just approve or sign off on any of the
paperwork that Complainant completed. Complainant said once she obtained her
6

bachelor's degree, she then was officially the case manager however none of her
duties changed as she was already completing all required case management work.
Case Manager Z was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4,
2022. Case Manager Z said she has been working at New Hope since January 3,
2022. Case Manager Z said Complainant had been the assistant case manager for
about six months prior to Case Manager Z being hired. Case Manager Z said it was
her understanding that Complainant was doing the case management job
supervised by Chief Administrator 2. Case Manager Z said when she was hired
there was supposed to be a transition time between her and Complainant, however
Complainant was terminated on the third day of the transition.
Chief Administrator 2 was interviewed via telephone on February 10, 2022.
Chief Administrator 2 said when she was moved to New Hope there was an
established case manager however that person ended employment the end of
September 2021 or beginning October 2021. Chief Administrator 2 said Complainant
then took over and was doing all of the case management paperwork until DCWL
denied the variance for her to be in that role the end of October 2021. Chief
Administrator 2 said at that time Complainant became assistant case manager and
Chief Administrator 2 said she was the formal case manager. Chief Administrator 2
said Complainant was completing reports and Chief Administrator 2 would read
behind her and give her corrections or teach her the appropriate way to complete a
report. Chief Administrator 2 said Complainant was also setting up family team
meetings, school conferences, and meeting with the youth. Chief Administrator 2
said she was sitting in on all of these meetings with Complainant. Chief
Administrator 2 said there was no one signing off on Chief Administrator 2’s work.
Chief Administrator 2 said the assistant case manager job was created specifically
for Complainant’s situation. Chief Administrator 2 said this decision was made by
Administrator.
Administrator was interviewed via telephone on February 10, 2022.
Administrator said he was the direct supervisor for Chief Administrator 2 while she
was employed at New Hope. Administrator said he was aware that Complainant was
denied the variance to be in that position. Administrator said Complainant was then
assigned as an assistant to continue to help Chief Administrator 2 completed the
tasks of case management similar to how Complainant was doing so while interning.
Administrator said he was unaware of the exact details of how Chief Administrator 2
put that into practice on a day-to-day basis however did direct Chief Administrator to
approve anything that Complainant completed. Administrator said New Hope posted
for the case manager position as soon as they had the denied variance for
Complainant. Administrator said he does not know who would have been signing off
on Chief Administrator 2’s work.
Documents Reviewed:
 Complainant’s personnel file: Complainant was hired on 1/6/2020 as a direct
care staff. Complainant was promoted to “assistant case manager” according
7

to an “employee data sheet” dated 10/25/2021 and signed by Chief
Administrator 2. Complainant obtained her bachelor’s degree in December
2021 and has been an employee of New Hope since January 2020 as a direct
care worker and participated in her internship at New Hope from May 2021-
August 2021.
 DCWL denied variance for Complainant to be the case manager, dated
10/29/2021.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4119 Social service worker; qualifications.
A social service worker, at the time of appointment to the
position, shall possess a bachelor's degree with a major in
a human behavioral science from an accredited college or
university or another major with 25% of credits in human
behavioral sciences.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance with social service worker
qualifications. Complainant did not have a bachelor’s degree
and was denied a variance from DCWL to be the case manager
in October 2021. The facility hired her as the assistant case
manager however according to interviews, Complainant still
completed all social service worker tasks and was supervised by
Chief Administrator 2. Despite the title of the position
Complainant was doing all social service worker duties while not
being qualified.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATIONS:
Youth are not receiving therapy as required.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth A
said she has been placed at New Hope since August 2021. Youth A said the
therapist left a “few months ago” and so she is now seeing Therapist and Clinical
Director for her therapy. Youth A said she has been meeting with Therapist two to
three times per week and will see Clinical Director “once and a while”. Youth A said
Therapist is aware of her treatment plan and goals and Youth A enjoys working with
Therapist.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth B
said she does not have a current therapist. Youth B said she has not had therapy in
about three months. Youth B said she has had suicidal ideations and the Clinical
Director was supposed to do an evaluation with her however has never come to do
8

the evaluation. Youth B said she has medication reviews however Case Manager Z
sits in those sessions. Youth B denied ever meeting with Therapist or Clinical
Director for therapy.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth C
said she has been placed at New Hope for about three months. Youth C said
therapy has been inconsistent for her. Youth C said Therapist is currently providing
therapy however she is not consistently around, and Youth C said she cannot
remember the last time she even met with Therapist was.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth D
said she has been placed at New Hope since November 9, 2021. Youth D said she
gets therapy about every three weeks. Youth D said Therapist is currently providing
her therapy. Youth D said she has not seen Clinical Director at New Hope. Youth D
said she feels she is not getting the therapy she needs to be successful.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face via TEAMS on January 13, 2022. Youth E
said she has been placed at New Hope since November 2021. Youth E said she
receives therapy each week with Therapist. Youth E said she and Therapist have
developed goals together and she has no concerns about her therapy.
Youth F was interviewed via telephone on February 9, 2022. Youth F said she
“barely” remembers being placed at New Hope stating it was “a year ago”. Youth F
said she thinks her therapist was Therapist and said she did not get therapy “much”.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4, 2022. Staff 2
said the New Hope therapist quit her job and the staff were told that Therapist and
Clinical Director were going to be filling in until someone new was permanently
hired. Staff 2 said the youth at New Hope are supposed to get group therapy three
times a week as well as individual therapy. Staff 2 said the group therapy has not
been occurring since Therapist and Clinical Director took over. Staff 2 said Therapist
has not been seeing the youth regularly and weeks have gone by, and Clinical
Director does not even come to the facility. Staff 2 said the therapy is “majorly
lacking” and the youth have been saying they need therapy but are not getting it.
Staff 2 said there have been youth that need “close observation” which requires a
therapist to do an evaluation however the evaluations are not being completed and
staff are just supervising closely. Staff 2 said for youth to come off “close
supervision” the therapist is supposed to evaluate the youth and make the decision
however that is not happening either and the youth will either be on “close
supervision” longer than needed, or staff are just making the decision and taking
them off.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4, 2022. Staff 3
said Therapist and Clinical Director are currently filling in to provide therapy and
have been since the prior therapist left in November. Staff 3 said the youth are all
offered weekly therapy however are not all participating. Staff 3 said Therapist was
9

coming to New Hope twice weekly, Tuesday and Fridays. Staff 3 said Clinical
Director was available via telephone as needed. Staff 3 said there is a new therapist
that would be starting February 4, 2022.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4, 2022. Staff 4
said Therapist was providing therapy twice per week for the youth since November.
Staff 4 said Clinical Director is now supposed to provide therapy however has not
been at the facility consistently. Staff 4 said the youth are all saying they do not feel
they are getting the therapy and treatment they need at this time.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on February 7, 2022. Complainant
said when she left New Hope the therapist that had been working with the youth was
gone and Therapist and Clinical Director were supposed to be providing therapy to
each of the youth. Complainant said in November, December, and the short time in
January that she was employed she did not see Clinical Director come to provide
any therapy for the youth at New Hope. Complainant said she did see Therapist
come once weekly and see as many youth as she was able to in her time there
however Therapist schedule was inconsistent and not all of the youth were getting
treatment.
Case Manager Z was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on February 4,
2022. Case Manager Z said she has been working at New Hope since January 3,
2022. Case Manager Z said Therapist was assigned to see all the youth for therapy
since she had been hired. Case Manager Z said Therapist would come to New Hope
once per week and see youth. Case Manager Z said Therapist would do “verbal”
treatment plans and goal with youth however did not do the written plans. Case
Manager Z said it is her understanding Clinical Director has been doing the written
treatment plans. Case Manager Z said she is unsure what the consistency has been
for youth receiving individual therapy. Case Manager Z said Clinical Director has
been filling in to do some therapy sessions since Therapist is no longer providing
therapy. Case Manager Z said Clinical Director has done zoom sessions and in
person sessions. Case Manager Z said she was told New Hope has a contracted
therapist that is supposed to start however has not done so to date. Case Manager
Z said after each therapy session there is a progress note that is written and filed in
each youth’s file.
Clinical Director was interviewed face-to-face at Evart Youth Center on
January 25, 2022. Clinical Director said she was the supervisor to the former New
Hope therapist and is the supervisor to Therapist. Clinical Director said Therapist
was filling in at New Hope after the former therapist left until they could hire a new
therapist. Clinical Director said Therapist was to be at New Hope two days per week
and run groups and individual sessions with the youth. Clinical Director said the
original plan was for Therapist and Clinical Director to fill in at New Hope together
however Clinical Director said the former therapist told the youth things that were not
true about her and so the youth refused to meet with her. Clinical Director said all of
10

the youth’s therapy sessions are documented on progress notes and in the youth’s
files.
Chief Administrator 2 was interviewed via telephone on February 10, 2022.
Chief Administrator 2 said when she started her employment there was an
established therapist working with all the youth that left the end of October 2021.
Chief Administrator 2 stated once this therapist left, Therapist and Clinical Director
divided the youth evenly and would provide twice weekly face-to-face therapy. Chief
Administrator 2 said each youth was getting at least weekly therapy. Chief
Administrator 2 said after each therapy session a progress note is completed and
placed in the youth’s files.
Documents Reviewed:
 Therapy Progress Notes for youth were reviewed on February 4, 2022.
Progress Notes were signed by the former therapist if completed in
September or October, and Therapist for November, December, and January.
There were no progress notes files for February. The progress notes
indicating therapy sessions for each youth are as follows:
o Youth A was placed at New Hope on 9/30/2021. She received therapy
on the following dates since placement: 10/29/21, 11/7/21, 11/19/21,
11/23/21, 12/10/21, 12/14/21, 12/28/21, 1/7/22, 1/11/22, 1/14/22.
o Youth B was placed at New Hope on 3/25/21. She received therapy on
the following dates between September 2021 and February 2022:
9/27/21, 9/28/21, 9/29/21, 10/5/21, 10/6/21, 10/8/21, 11/30/21, 12/1/21,
12/2/21, 12/3/21, 12/8/21, 1/7/22.
o Youth C was placed at New Hope on 10/1/2021. She received therapy
on the following dates since placement: 11/7/21, 12/28/21, 1/7/22,
1/14/22.
o Youth D was placed at New Hope on 11/9/21. She received therapy on
the following dates since placement: 11/14/21, 11/23/21, 11/30/21,
12/7/21, 12/14/21, 12/21/21, 12/31/21, 1/7/22, 1/14/22.
o Youth E was placed at New Hope on 11/10/21. She received therapy
on the following dates since placement: 12/28/21, 1/7/22.
o Youth G was placed at New Hope on 1/25/22. She has not received
any therapy since her placement.
o Youth H was placed at New Hope on 12/20/21. She has received
therapy on the following dates since placement: 12/31/21, 1/7/22,
1/11/22.
o Youth I was placed at New Hope on 11/16/21. She has received
therapy on the following dates since placement: 11/19/21, 11/23/21,
12/3/21, 12/10/21, 12/17/21, 12/22/21, 12/28/21, 12/31/21, 1/7/22.
o Youth J was placed at New Hope on 9/22/21. She has received
therapy on the following dates since placement: 9/28/21, 9/29/21,
9/30/21, 10/29/21, 11/4/21, 11/7/21, 12/31/21, 1/7/22.
11

o Youth K was placed at New Hope on 11/16/21. She received therapy
on the following dates since placement: 11/19/21, 12/3/21, 12/10/21,
12/17/21, 12/21/21, 12/28/21.
APPLICABLE RULE
RFCAN pg. 20 Individual or Group Therapy
The contractor must provide at a minimum weekly direct
therapy services for each youth individually; group therapy
can be used as an adjunct treatment. Individual and/or
group therapy must be provided in accordance with the
youth’s treatment needs as identified in the youth’s service
plan.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance with Individual or Group
Therapy. After interviews and review of files, the youth were not
getting consistent weekly therapy sessions as required by
contract.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Therapist is not qualified to provide therapy.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Chief Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the Evart Youth Center
facility on January 25, 2022, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Chief
Administrator 1 said the facility was found in violation of Therapist not having her
license during investigation at Evart Youth Center in November 2021. Chief
Administrator 1 said it was his understanding that Therapist had applied for her
LLMSW on November 1, 2021, and had been waiting for the hardcopy of the license
to come in the mail. Chief Administrator 1 said Therapist used the facility credit card
to pay the fees to LARA to obtain her LLMSW. Chief Administrator 1 said he did not
know until it was brought up again on January 21, 2022, that Therapist had not
followed through on what was needed to obtain her license. Chief Administrator 1
said he is aware that Therapist was assigned to provide therapy to the youth at New
Hope.
Clinical Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on January 25,
2022, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Clinical Director said she is the
supervisor of Therapist. Clinical Director said she was aware that Therapist had a

ANALYSIS: The facility is found in non-compliance with RFCAN Staff
Education and Staff Qualifications. The facility was aware
through a different special investigation that Therapist did not
have her license. Therapist continued to provide therapy to
youth at New Hope between 11/1/2021 and 1/21/2022.
Therapist’s file did not contain evidence of licensure. All
documentations and interviews revealed Therapist did not follow
through to obtain her LLMSW.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
